feed.title: The Register
feed.subtitle: Biting the hand that feeds IT — sci/tech news and views for the world

entry.title: Still hanging round: Kim Dotcom extradition hearings delayed
entry.summary:
Also: Internet Party in the doldrums

Kim Dotcom will be waiting until nearly the end of this year to find out whether American courts will get their hands on him: an extradition hearing due in April 2014 has been delayed, with a new date yet to be set.…

entry.title: Pony up: More Bitcoins go missing to theives
entry.summary:
Yet another Bitcoin heist-bot

Another $200,000-plus worth of Bitcoins has been lifted, according to Trustwave, which has identified a new Pony botnet targeting crypto-currencies.…

entry.title: Wilocity uncloaks 4.6Gb/sec Wi-Fi for next year's smartphones
entry.summary:
Low-power 'Sparrow' flies into Barcelona, renamed Wil6300

MWC 2014  Wilocity, pioneers of high-speed "WiGig" 60GHz Wi-Fi, has used the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona as the debutant ball for its 4.6Gb/sec chip for smartphones, formerly codenamed "Sparrow" and now formally dubbed Wil6300.…

entry.title: NHMRC: wind turbines still can't be fingered as killers
entry.summary:
NHMRC: wind turbines still can't be fingered as killers

The twentieth review of the impact of wind turbines on human health in Australia since 2003 has found the same thing that the previous 19 found: there's no evidence that wind turbines have any impact on human health.…

entry.title: MtGox MELTDOWN: Quits Bitcoin Foundation board, deletes Twitter
entry.summary:
Second board member to resign in two months amid murky dealings

Embattled Bitcoin exchange MtGox has taken steps to withdraw itself from the wider Bitcoin community, having resigned its seat on the Bitcoin Foundation board and reduced its presence in social media.…

entry.title: What's up with that WhatsApp $19bn price tag? Answer: Voice calls
entry.summary:
Now you can text and talk on your phone! RIP the mobile network business as we know it

Multibillion-dollar chat app WhatsApp will let users make voice calls, it was announced today.…

entry.title: Sandisk breaks 128GB barrier with new $199 MICROSD card
entry.summary:
Silly amounts of storage on a fingernail-sized sliver

Ten years ago SanDisk showed off its first microSD card with what was then an impressive 128MB storage. Now the company has unveiled a 128GB model, specially designed for use in Android smartphones.…

entry.title: Wanna change the world but need cash? Fret not: Billionaire Eric Schmidt has some spare change
entry.summary:
A million dollars up for grabs just in time for a book launch

Billionaire Google executive chairman Eric Schmidt is putting up one million dollars of his own money to fund technological innovation.…

entry.title: Moon flashes Earth after getting pounding from MASSIVE meteorite
entry.summary:
Largest impact yet recorded visible from our world

Video  Scientists have reported spotting the biggest meteorite impact ever seen on the Moon's surface – after a 400kg (900lb) rock slammed into the lunar regolith at an estimated 17km/s, leaving a crater about 50 metres wide.…

entry.title: Prez Obama cyber-guru: Think your data is safe in an EU cloud? The NSA will raid your servers
entry.summary:
But US govt shouldn't be 'f**king' with crypto algorithms

A former White House security advisor has suggested that you, dear reader, are naive if you think hosting data outside of the US will protect a business from the NSA.…

entry.title: Tizen devices are HERE ... and they're Samsung Gear 2 smartwatches

entry.title: 1bn down, 6bn to go: Zuck to grow Facebook by touting 'free internet onramp' for the poor

entry.title: Chipzilla just won't quit: Intel touts 64-bit Atoms for Android phones, tabs
entry.summary:
No easy ride for Apple, ARM et al – and there's an 300Mbps LTE chip in the works

MWC 2014  Intel has launched one new 64-bit, Android-capable Atom processor platform – "Merrifield" – taken the wraps off a future one – "Moorefield" – and introduced a new LTE modem in its latest bid to crack the mobile market as well as position itself for the buzzword du jour, the Internet of Things.…

entry.title: NBN Co tells iiNet told to use Broadcom chips in VDSL routers
entry.summary:
ISP also planning Zigbee-powered connected home router

iiNet, Australia's third-largest internet service provider in terms of subscriber numbers, has been told by NBNCo that it should consider only Broadcom chipsets for its future VDSL modems.…

MWC 2014  Ever in search of the next few billion people who will access the internet for the first time in the coming years, Mozilla has unveiled a reference design of a smartphone that it says could sell for as low as $25 (£15).…

IBM is creeping towards the cloud, picking up startups on the way, including a NoSQL database company to fill in some of the perceived shortcomings of DB2.…

entry.title: Ghostwriter: Assange™ is NARCISSISTIC and UNTRUTHFUL

'Thin-skinned' WikiLeaker torpedoed own multi-million-dollar book deal

The ghost writer hired to help Julian Assange with an autobiography deal that ultimately fell apart has described the WikiLeaker as "thin-skinned, conspiratorial, untruthful and narcissistic".…

entry.title: UK citizens to Microsoft: Oi. We WANT ODF as our doc standard
entry.summary:
Open source zealots beat down on OOXML as consultation continues

Even if Microsoft bosses collectively whistled Always Look on the Bright Side of Life they'd still struggle to drown out people backing Cabinet Office proposals to adopt the Open Document Format as the official standard for UK.gov missives.…

entry.title: Mobile World Congress: It's not about the SHINY SHINY anymore
entry.summary:
You don't put devices into containers... you put containers into devices

Comment  The industry hog roast and hoedown that is Mobile World Congress used to be all about who had the shiniest new smartphone, tablet or random mobile-related gadget. But things have changed.…

entry.title: Supercomputer maker Cray: Jobs for HPC kids? There might be some going

Cluster veep John Lee on SCC

HPC blog  There are some teens and kids in their twenties who skip out on university courses for a trip abroad with their friends, where they spend days and nights chugging down (caffeine) brew, losing sleep and wrestling with, er, clusters. But this isn't necessarily a bad thing...…

entry.title: Cheap'n'cheerful Chinese mobesters ZTE launch Firefox phones
entry.summary:
Billion-unit shipment hopes for Open C and Open II

MWC 2014  As Telefonica pushes Firefox as a foil to the dominance of Apple and Android, ZTE is keen to play ball with a couple of new Firefox phones. Called the Open C and Open II, they are looking to ship more than one million devices this year. The new phones run Firefox OS 1.3.…

entry.title: Stuff the delays! PM chuffed to have BT's superfast broadband in his constituency
entry.summary:
'It's great', says David Cameron

Prime Minister David Cameron already enjoys super speedy internet connections at his constituency home in Dean, Oxfordshire, but locals in the village of Alvescot – saddled with a very slow broadband service – have waited a long time for an upgrade.…

entry.title: Nokia launches Euro ANDROID invasion, quips: 'Microsoft knew what they were buying'

MWC 2014  Microsoft was aware of Nokia's plans to release a range of Android phones, the man in charge of the new range told us today. And the new Nokiadroids - of which there are more than anyone predicted - will be coming to the UK - possibly sooner than anyone realises.…

entry.title: Future storage tech should KILL all-in-one solutions, says CEO
entry.summary:
DataCore boss waxes lyrical on software-defined storage

El Reg had a conversation with DataCore president, CEO and co-founder George Teixeira about what’s likely to happen in 2014 with DataCore. Software-defined storage represents a trend that his company is well-positioned to take advantage of and he reckons DataCore could soar this year.…

entry.title: Battle of Bletchley Park: TNMOC chief calls for review of museums' Mexican standoff
entry.summary:
Iraq dossier MI6 chief's 'Disneyland' plans blasted

The National Museum of Computing has called for an independent review in a bid to solve a long-running dispute with the Bletchley Park Trust - chaired by ex-MI6 chief (or "C") Sir John Scarlett, famous for overseeing production of the dossier which took Britain to war in Iraq.…

entry.title: Enterprising French chap cranks up €100k 'flying car'

entry.title: Mobe operators, need to check your network? There’s an app for that
entry.summary:

MWC 2014  US mobile network checking company Global Wireless Solutions says there is a gap between its traditional way of testing mobile coverage using vans driving around with $300k of testing kit in the back and crowd-sourced reports on quality of mobile network coverage.…

entry.title: NHS England DIDN'T tell households about GP medical data grab plan
entry.summary:
'Junk mail' leaflet not important enough for special attention, apparently

NHS England patients who went to the trouble of opting themselves out of junk mail being crammed through their letterboxes did not receive the health service's recent leaflet about its data grab plan with GP medical records, it has been revealed.…

entry.title: WhatsApp founder: Believe us, internet! 'Twas a DODGY network router WOT DONE IT
entry.summary:

entry.title: Pics: 'Bitcoin ATMs' spring up in the US

entry.title: Yes! New company smartphones! ... But I don't WANT one
entry.summary:
Since I don't have an iPhone with a worn out battery

Sysadmin Blog  It's mobile update month at my company, and that means it's time for a look at the smartphones. I've researched every single unit that will work on a Canadian cellular network and come to some interesting conclusions. For the first time I'm looking at a refresh cycle more from the standpoint of a business owner and end-user rather than as a gadget-obsessed nerd and that changes things significantly.…

entry.title: Cloud Foundry laps up attention in EMC, IBM, HP, Rackspace, SAP, VMware love-in

The Cloud Foundry open-source project looks set to become a standard piece of technology in the thriving distributed systems ecosystem: its main backer, Pivotal, has persuaded IBM, HP, SAP and Rackspace to join a new foundation dedicated to the tech.…

entry.title: MIT wants quasars to help put free will to rest
entry.summary:
Ringing the Bell on inequality

The last of three loopholes held to remain in Bell's Theorem, “setting independence”, is under the spotlight with an MIT research group saying that quasars could be used as random number generators and help prove* the validity of quantum mechanics.…

A draft put forward to the Internet Engineering Task Force has drawn the ire of prominent privacy activist Lauren Weinstein as “one of the most alarming Internet proposals” he's ever seen.…

entry.title: Microsoft may slash price of Windows 8.1 on cheap 'slabs
entry.summary:
Report says 70 per cent discount for OEMs willing to make sub-$US250 devices

entry.title: Curiosity now going BACKWARDS
entry.summary:
There's no spare parts shop on Mars

Putting a nuclear-powered, laser-armed space tank on Mars is one of humanity’s most remarkable achievements, and now we've even figured out how to make it go backwards!…

entry.title: Collective SSL FAIL a symptom of software's cultural malaise
entry.summary:
Apple, WhatsApp and Belkin show that if you ask for bad software, you get bad software

In the 19 years that have passed since the first implementation of SSL, you could be forgiven for expecting that the industry could do it right by now: and yet last week, not one but three SSL vendors were discovered to have implementation problems.…

entry.title: G20 gives Google, Microsoft, Apple et al tax deadline
entry.summary:

The world's top 20 finance ministers have signalled once again that they're sick of their taxes disappearing offshore and have signalled a strong intention to get their cash back.…

entry.title: Microsoft courts mobe-makers, tweaks Windows 8 for WIMPs
